title: Structural Complexities of Matching MechanismsWe thank Nick Arnosti, Aram Grigoryan, Andreas Haupt, Ori Heffetz, Jacob Leshno, Irene Lo, Kunal Mittal, S. Matthew Weinberg, and seminar participants at Princeton for illuminating discussions and helpful feedback.
abstract:
We study various novel complexity measures for two-sided matching mechanisms, applied to the two canonical strategyproof matching mechanisms,
Deferred Acceptance (𝖣𝖠𝖣𝖠\mathsf{DA}) and Top Trading Cycles (𝖳𝖳𝖢𝖳𝖳𝖢{{\mathsf{TTC}}}).
Our metrics are designed to capture the complexity of various structural (rather than computational) concerns, in particular ones of recent interest within economics.
We consider a canonical, flexible approach to formalizing our questions: define a protocol or data structure performing some task, and bound the number of bits that it requires.
Our main results apply this approach to four questions of general interest; for mechanisms matching applicants to institutions, our questions are:


(1)

How can one applicant affect the outcome matching?



(2)

How can one applicant affect another applicant’s set of options?



(3)

How can the outcome matching be represented / communicated?



(4)

How can the outcome matching be verified?



We prove that 𝖣𝖠𝖣𝖠\mathsf{DA} and 𝖳𝖳𝖢𝖳𝖳𝖢{{\mathsf{TTC}}} are comparable in complexity under questions (1) and (4), giving new tight lower-bound constructions and new verification protocols. Under both questions (2) and (3), we prove that 𝖳𝖳𝖢𝖳𝖳𝖢{{\mathsf{TTC}}} is more complex than 𝖣𝖠𝖣𝖠\mathsf{DA}.
For question (2), we prove this by giving a new combinatorial characterization of which institutions are removed from each applicant’s set of options when a new applicant is added in 𝖣𝖠𝖣𝖠\mathsf{DA}; this characterization may be of independent interest.
For question (3), our result gives lower bounds proving the tightness of existing constructions for 𝖳𝖳𝖢𝖳𝖳𝖢{{\mathsf{TTC}}}. This shows that the relationship between the matching and the priorities is more complex in 𝖳𝖳𝖢𝖳𝖳𝖢{{\mathsf{TTC}}} than in 𝖣𝖠𝖣𝖠\mathsf{DA}, formalizing previous intuitions within the economics literature [LL21, AL16]. Together, our results complement recent work that models the complexity of observing strategyproofness and shows that 𝖣𝖠𝖣𝖠\mathsf{DA} is more complex than 𝖳𝖳𝖢𝖳𝖳𝖢{{\mathsf{TTC}}} [GHT22]. This emphasizes that diverse considerations must factor into gauging the complexity of matching mechanisms.
